title: How to Open Film for Developing (and Free Trapped Film)

steps.title: Turn the film canister so the flat bottom is facing up.
steps.content: Turn the film canister so the flat bottom is facing up. Film canisters are like small cans with a lid. The flat side is the lid of the canister. This is the part that comes off so you can get the film out. [1] X Research source The other end has a knob for rolling the film. Don’t open the canister from this side. If you're taking the film out to develop it, make sure you're in a dark room. You'll have to feel around so you can tell which side is flat and which one has a knob.

steps.title: Pop the lid off with a bottle opener.
steps.content: Pop the lid off with a bottle opener. Angle the bottle opener so the notch is just below the edge of the lid. Pry up until the lid pops off, just like if you were opening a beer or soda. [2] X Research source It might be tough to find the canister edge in the dark. Feel around a little and you’ll be able to catch the edge of the lid with the notch on the bottle opener.

steps.title: Slide the film out of the canister.
steps.content: Slide the film out of the canister. Simply turn the canister and let the film fall out into your other hand. You might have to give it a little shake or pull to get it out. [3] X Research source Only touch the edges of the film when you take it out. Otherwise you could ruin the pictures. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Recycle the canister when you’re done.
steps.content: Recycle the canister when you’re done. Most film canisters are single-use, so there’s no need to keep them once you take the film out. Throw the empty canister in your plastic recycling bin to get rid of it. [5] X Research source If you’re using a reusable canister, then don’t get rid of it. You can refill it with fresh film and take more pictures.

steps.title: Find the ridge along the side of the canister.
steps.content: Find the ridge along the side of the canister. Film canisters have a plastic or metal ridge running up the side. Find this and turn the canister so the ridge is facing you. [6] X Research source Make sure you’re in a dark room if you took pictures with this film. It’s pretty easy to feel along the canister and find the ridge in the dark. Some reusable film canisters don’t have this ridge. In this case, pop the lid off with a bottle opener or your fingers instead.

steps.title: Tuck your fingers just under the ridge.
steps.content: Tuck your fingers just under the ridge. Hold the canister tightly with one hand. Then get a good grip on the ridge with your other hand by wrapping your fingers under it. [7] X Research source You could also use a bottle opener for this method. Tuck the notch under the ridge instead of the canister lid.

steps.title: Pull the ridge back until the canister opens up.
steps.content: Pull the ridge back until the canister opens up. Give the ridge a good pull backward like you're trying to unwrap it. The plastic should peel back and expose the film inside the canister. Keep pulling to unwrap the entire canister. [8] X Research source This takes some strength, so don’t be afraid to pull hard! You’ll also need a good grip on the canister with your other hand, so hold tight.

steps.title: Pull the film out of the canister.
steps.content: Pull the film out of the canister. When you remove the film, remember to only touch it on the edges so you don't ruin the pictures. You can now put it on a reel to develop. [9] X Research source The canister will be broken after this, so recycle it when you’re done.

steps.title: Roll the film until you hear a click inside the canister.
steps.content: Roll the film until you hear a click inside the canister. This is a good trick if you accidentally rolled the film too much and it's stuck in the canister. Hold the canister so the ridge is on top of it and facing away from you. Turn the knob on top of the canister toward you to roll the film inside. When you hear a slight click, that means the film is right past the ridge on the canister where it’s supposed to come out. [10] X Research source It might be hard to hear this click, so hold the canister up to your ear if you’re not hearing it. If you're trying to get out film that you took pictures with, make sure you're in a dark room so the photos aren't ruined.

steps.title: Wet the tip of another roll of film.
steps.content: Wet the tip of another roll of film. Get another roll of film and pull the tip out about 2–3 in (5.1–7.6 cm). Dip it in a bit of water. This makes it stick to the other film roll and pull it out, and it won’t damage the film. [11] X Research source If you don’t have water, you could also lick the film. There are also tools you can buy to get trapped film out of the canister. This is just a DIY trick.

steps.title: Slide the tip of film inside the other film canister.
steps.content: Slide the tip of film inside the other film canister. Find the ridge on the side of the canister that the film is stuck in. Slide the tip of the other film roll inside the slit on the ridge. Insert it about 1 in (2.5 cm) so the two pieces of film come into contact. [12] X Research source You might feel a bit more resistance when the two pieces of film meet, so you’ll know the film is in far enough.

steps.title: Roll the canister until the new piece of film starts going inside.
steps.content: Roll the canister until the new piece of film starts going inside. Turn the knob on top of the canister toward you again to roll the film. If the two pieces are connected, then the new piece of film should start rolling into the canister. Keep turning until the film goes another 1 in (2.5 cm) into the canister. [13] X Research source If the film isn’t moving, then the pieces may not have come into contact. Pull the film out and re-wet it to try again.

steps.title: Pull the film out to free the trapped roll.
steps.content: Pull the film out to free the trapped roll. Give the film that you inserted into the canister a good, quick tug. If the two pieces of film are attached, then the trapped piece will come out of the slit along with the piece you put in. You can then load the canister into a camera or pull the film roll out if you want to. [14] X Research source Don’t pull the film slowly. The two pieces could detach before the trapped one comes out. Always let the film dry before loading it into a camera or developing it.
